description: From Middle English escheker, from Anglo-Norman escheker (“chessboard”); from Medieval Latin scaccarium. This is because the cloth on which the exchequer counted money was chequered like a chessboard.

entries.meaning: An available fund of money, especially one for a specific purpose.

verbs.description: exchequer (third-person singular simple present exchequers, present participle exchequering, simple past and past participle exchequered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To proceed against (a person) in the Court of Exchequer.
